title: Home Depot Posts Higher Sales as Transactions Continue to Drop; Customers spent 9.1% more on average, while tally of total transactions fell for fifth quarter in a row
text:

Meanwhile, average transaction value has increased each quarter, often by more than 10% year over year as the company continues to raise prices across its stores to combat rising inflation.

Second-quarter sales came in at $43.79 billion, ahead of Wall Street expectations of $43.36 billion, according to FactSet. Same-store sales, which adjusts for store openings and closings, were up 5.8%, including 5.4% in the U.S.

Home Depot executives said Tuesday that elevated home values have kept demand strong from both professional contractors and do-it-yourself customers.

"When you look at the wealth creation over the last two years, home price appreciation of almost 40%, our customer is just in a really good place right now," Chief Financial Officer Richard McPhail said on the company's earnings call.

Rising interest rates have pushed some potential home buyers out of the housing market in recent months, but that hasn't impacted Home Depot sales yet, Chief Executive Ted Decker said.

Higher prices may have turned some inflation-addled customers away from big-ticket items such as grills and mowers, but spending in paint and other large renovation categories has remained strong, the company said.

One category where prices are down is lumber, which has come off highs in recent months and ate into Home Depot's average ticket growth for the second quarter.

For the three months ended July 31, Home Depot posted earnings of $5.17 billion, or $5.05 a share, compared with $4.81 billion, or $4.53 a share, in the same quarter last year. Wall Street analysts had expected earnings of $4.95 a share.

The company reaffirmed its guidance for revenue to rise 3% this year, saying it still expects weaker year-over-year sales growth in the second half of 2022. Per-share earnings are expected to rise at a mid-single-digit rate.

Home Depot shares rose 3.6% to $325.83 in early trading. They are down more than 21.5% this year.
